Social Penetration

Social Penetration theory explains how self-disclosure influences the progression of a relationship towards intimacy. An onion metaphor is used to portray the different layers of information that we share in various relationships. The superficial layer is biographical information we share in new relationships, while the core layer contains information about our self-identity.

------breadth------                    

<--- depth

Breadth


The variety of topics that have been incorporated into individuals' lives.

Depth


The amount of information available on each topic.

Superficial


This stage, also known as the orientation stage, is where friendships are initiated. This is where simple small talk and harmless clichés like “That’s cool" or "Good for you" are often used. In this stage people tend to follow the social norm of appropriateness and act in desirable behaviors so that they can make a good first impression and get what they want (usually a friendship, or to become better acclimated at work and school).

Middle


This stage is known as the exploratory stage.  As the relationship develops, individuals will begin to express feelings, beliefs, and opinions towards moderate topics, such as politics or education.  Individuals won't usually express the whole truth, hiding parts for the sake of acceptance because they won't be comfortable enough to share some of their deeper and more intimate feelings. Most relationships do not move beyond this stage.

Inner


The affective stage is where people start to talk about private and personal matters. As intimacy and trust are built, people become more comfortable in exchanging secrets, dreams, hopes, or fears.  Criticism and arguments, which were rare before, start to rise and became more common. Other types of communication such as touching begin to occur in this stage. This stage equivalent to romantic couples, married couples, or best friends.

Core


The core or stable stage is where the relationship starts to stabilize. Individuals who have know each other for a long period of time express an immediate connection and can predict the emotional reactions of the other person. They may know each other’s feelings by noticing the nonverbal (face expression, body language) communication of the other person. Altman and Taylor observed that the relationship reaches a plateau because there is not much left to disclose.

We will weigh the COSTS and REWARDS associated with self-disclosure.

Level 1: Superficial

Level 2: Middle

Level 3: Inner

Level 4: Core
